data_answer: Windmills have been used by American colonists to perform numerous functions, such as pumping water and cutting wood. They have now, in modern times, become one of the most cost effective technologies. Although they are so, windmills have many disadvantages due to its negative effects on the environment. In order to create windmills, the habitats of many animals are destroyed. New sections of land need to be cleared in order to have a place for the windmills to be. This in turn results in the destruction of homes for many animals, forcing them to become endangered due to the lack of both shelter and food. For example, the production of these windmills causes trees, a bird's home, to be chopped down in order to provide room for these windmills. These birds now don't have any home and are forced to migrate to find a different one. Although windmills don't cause pollution in the air or radioactive waste, it is capable of causing noise pollution. The sounds that the windmills make a very loud and distracting for thet people that live there and help to ruin the pristine and beautiful landscape. Windmills help to make areas that were once beautiful, ugly and uninviting. It is easy of seeing just how efficient windmills are, but one can't deny the negative effects that surround them. In order to produce windmills, the pristine quality of the rural landscape is destroyed, and so is the habitats of various animals. These effects produce drastinc changes in our environment that are both negative and destructive.

label: TRAINING
data_answer: Wind power is an ineffective source of "clean" energy. Wind patterns are unpredictable, and it is often unlikely that wind will continually run through a certain area where the wind generators are. Therefore, the turbines may sit static for long periods of time without generating any electric power. Wind speed varies by 10%, and turbine power varies by 25%. The wind which passes through the turbines also varies on the environment where it is placed. If a turbine is placed near trees, tall buildings or mountains, the wind will be affected by the large structures, and little will pass through the blades of the turbine. Wind turbines are large, ugly contraptions which ruin scenic rural landscapes. The large blades of the turbine are a reminder of failed technology in a place where nature rules its realm. The rotating blades of the generator also endanger native wildlife, including migrating birds, who are struck down from the sky on their way to a better climate. During storms, many wind turbines are struck by lightning. It is expensive to make these required repairs. Comparable to a small jet engine, wind farms create noise pollution which is disturbing to their environment.

label: TRAINING
data_answer: Wind cannot be the sole source of power production for the power grid, as too many variables go into how well it is functioning. The wind is not always blowing powerfully enough to turn windmills with enough speed to generate power, and on other occasions it does not blow at all. There can be up to a ten percent difference in wind speed, and this can lead to an upwards of twenty five percent decrease in electrical output, and on the scale of millions of home, the results could be catastrophic. Not only does wind not blow regularly, but it also sometimes cannot blow at all, as natural formations such as hill, trees, or mountains can stop the wind from reaching the windmills, and many artificial structures can do this as well, such as skyscrapers or factories. If homes are built too close, they could potentially block out their own power source, or if the wind does get there, have to live with the equivalent of a small jet turbine constantly droning in their ears daily, as well as having to look at tall, unsightly pillars of whirrling blades constantly spinning and ruining the scenery that used to be there. If inconvenient living wasn't bad enough, then the sight of magled bird bodies would be the final nail in wind powers coffin. Like fishing nets, windmills often catch unlucky, unintenional animals, but unlike fishing nets where the animal has a chance of being noticed and released, a bird caught in a windmill's blades if cut by a sharp sheet of heavy metal, with absolutely no possiblity of recovery. Those who may not care about animal welfare will certainly worry when electrical output drops sharply because a goose hit a blade the wrong way and took down the entire windmill, causing the line to be severed, as well as cutting into profit margins by needing to have to replace it or repair it. For all these reasons, wind power is impractical, unstable, and a mere helping hand to fossil fuel driven plants at best.

These negative aspects include: noisiness, the wind not blowing at all times, the obstructions that block the wind from generating power, the massive turbines, the variation of wind speed correlating with wind power, wildlife such as birds becoming obstruced in the blades of the windmill, lightning damage that the turbines receive during storms, and the noise pollution that the turbines generate. These disadvantages of wind power have led many to argue whether or not wind power is actually worth using when it is much more efficient (though harmful) to just use gasoline, or other sources of energy that are faster in producing power.

Wind power is not a strong option for a renewable energy source due to its unpredictable and inefficient nature and its enviromental and asthetic impact.

data_answer: Altough wind energy is a seemingly viable option, there are many disadvantages to this kind of energy. Wind energy is not completely efficient because wind is not constantly blowing 24 hours a day. They are also hard to place because they loud, big, and need to be in an area with little obstructions and high wind speeds. Creating more turbines with large blades can endanger birds that are migrating to the south. label: TRAINING
data_answer: Despite the potential benefits of wind energy, there are many disadvantages that negate the effects of the advantages. Wind is not an entirely predictable force; wind speed varies by 10% in most locations. Other obstructions, such as forests, mountains, and man-made structures, can serve as barriers to the wind-flow, cutting off wind from the turbine locations. Wind is not constant, and times of stiller air could result in a loss of energy, especially to a population entirely dependent upon wind energy. While wind energy is hailed as a "green" alternative to current energy sources, the turbines necessary for generating Wind Power bear their own ecological implications. Turbines create a very real threat to already endangered wildlife, especially migratory birds. These bird are not familiar with the turbines and are often injured by the large propellors. Wind farms also present complications to human populations. The noise pollution produced by a wind farm is equivilent to that produced by a small jet engine. Turbines are bulky and almost agressively contemporary, and their presence often scars previously rural landscapes. The complications associated with Wind Power override any benefits Wind Power might provide.

label: TRAINING
data_answer: Within the past century, many alternative sources of energy have been produced. These alternative sources of energy, including harnessing wind energy, have reduced pollution. However, questions still arise as to how substantial wind energy have actually reduced pollution as well as provide a consistently clean energy source. Wind power is widely limited by geographic boundaries and degredates wildlife. Wind power needs to be located in areas with a large amount of wind flowing into the area. Most windmills are located in rural areas where wildlife may have thrived before these urban generators came to use. The blades of windmills are not protected by any gate, thus making birds vulnerable to flying into the blades. Although wind power reduces pollutants in the air, it further endangers ecosystems and its inhabitants. Furthermore, windmills need to be located in areas that get a persistent amount of wind to power the mills.

label: TRAINING
data_answer: Although the western and mid-western sections of the United States have taken a liking to the potenial energy that the wind harnesses, but the wind is not "a continually renewable and permanent [source of] energy". As stated: "[the wind] is free in abundance in certain areas...such as on the shoreline, at the top of a hill, and in places free of obstructions"; therefore, this source of renewable energy is unavailable to large populations within the boundaries of forests and mountains, tall-standing building and other man-made structures. How does one create space for the massive and ugly design of a wind-powered machine without destroying rural landscape? It is impossible.

label: TRAINING
data_answer: Many researchers advocate for utilization of wind energy, but the dependability of the "renewable source" is open for speculation. Wind mills certainly have the power to bring in significant amounts of energy to industrial and recreational machines, but are they worth it? Given differing weather patterns and daily fluctuations, the amount of wind energy that can be harnassed varies by the hour, decreasing reliability for anyone depending on only one or two turbines. Of course, if wind power generation becomes more popular, there will be wind farms across the U.S. and maybe the rest of the planet, but a great number of private property owners will want to take advantage of the resource for themselves, which will leave them with an inconstant energy supply. On top of the reliability issue, there is the matter of cost. Every single would-be wind farm requires many powerful turbines, which are not cheap. Each turbine will undoubtedly save money that might be spent on more traditional energy sources, but that money will need to be spent on maintenance and development of the turbines. With the high costs of wind energy equipment, it would take -at least- decades to reach a point in time where the low energy costs would compensate for the extreme initial costs. So, in a time of severe national debt and government concern over international social conflicts, mass spending by government offices for the sake of a long-term, somewhat experimental project can wait.

data_answer: Windmills are used to create wind energy for electricty. Also known as Wind Power, it can generate enough energy for a large amount of people in different areas. In 2012, the United States wind turbines generated about 3% of total U.S. electricity of about 12 million household. Even though windmills were used to generate electricity decades ago, like in 1920 Americans used small windmills to generate electricity in rural areas that lacked electricity, todays windmills are much more advanced. With new technology, the cost of residential wind power turbines has decreased over choice to pay more for electricity that comes from renewable sources to support new technologies. Growth in wind power has been encouraged by tax breaks for renewable energy. However, Wind Power is free and in abundance in certain areas especially where wind speed are always higher such as on a shore line. Wind is an excellent supplement to other renewable resources such as solar and hyroelectric power, but it does not generate pollution or radioactive waste. It also does not consume any of the non-renewable resources such as caol, natural gas, or oil. Although, it is the sole source of power during times when the electrical grid is out, mainly when enduring hurricanes, power outages, or brown outs. Overall, wind is a clean source of energy, the use of wind for energy has fewer enviromental impacts than using many other energy sources. Even though it may only be used for one major effect, it is a great reliable source for this effect.

label: TRAINING
data_answer: While wind power may be free and environmentally friendly, there are many practical disadvanteges to using wind as an energy source. For example, wind does not blow all the time, which means that wind power will not be sufficient to generate enough energy for everyone. Some may argue that larger turbines would solve this problem; however, their ugly design will ruin the rural landscape, and the noisy blades can also disturb residents. In addition to the aesthetic disadvantages of turbines, there are also many obstructions to building such structures such as forests, mountains, buildings, and other man-made structures. Another supposed advantage of wind power is its efficiency and its ability to be environmentally friendly. However, wind speeds vary by 10% and turbine power varies by 25%, proving that this efficiency is not consistent or stable enough to warrant widespread use of wind power. In addition, there are also many environmental hazards to wind power. For example, the large turbines can threaten endangered wildlife and endanger migrating birds. In addition, turbines may succumb to lightning damage, requiring maintenance costs. Finally, the turbines may also contribute to noise pollution. Thus, while wind energy may seem beneficial in theory, in practice it is not a plausible source of energy.

Wind turbines are believed to have minimal environmental impact because they don't produce waste, don't create pollution or radioactive waste, and they don't consume non-renewable resources like coal or oil. Even though they are believed to have no negative environmental effects, this is simply not true. The blades on wind turbines are incredibly noisy, and create large amounts of noise pollution. This noise pollution disrupts the surrounding environment and can cause wildlife to migrate away from the area. This noise pollution disrupts the balance in the ecosystem. Besides causing animals to move away from the area, wind turbines can also endanger the wildlife directly. Often times birds will be flying and be struck by the enormous blades. The blades cause a real danger to migrating birds and can kill them in large amounts. The noise pollution created by wind turbines, and the danger they pose to wildlife are two ways that wind turbines are not as useful of an energy source as people believe. Besides being a danger to the surrounding ecosystems and wildlife, wind turbine farms ruin rural landscapes. Wind farms must be placed in open, unindustrialized areas to catch the most wind and be the most productive. This means that wind farms need to be placed in rural landscapes. In placing wind turbines in these areas, we ruin the beauty of the surrounding nature. Turbines are large and ugly in design and cause an eye sore where there could be extreme natural beauty. The last issue that wind turbines pose is that they are not as resourseful as people believe. Wind does not constantly blow, and thus wind turbines are often not generating any energy at all. Even when the wind is blowing, the windspeed can vary by 10%. This can cause the wind turbine power to vary by 25% which does not make it a stable energy source for the entire population, or any population. Wind turbines are limited in where you can place them as well. The area can not be obstructed by any large buildings, man-made structures, forests, or mountains. This means we are very limited in where we can place these wind farms. Over all, wind turbines are more trouble than they are worth, they harm the environment through means other than pollution and waste, and they are not a reliable source of energy.

label: TRAINING
data_answer: Though wind power is a cleaner source of energy than, say, burning fossil fuels, it has several drawbacks. For example, wind speed is not constant. Wind does not blow twenty-four hours a day, seven days a week. Winds are the outcome of moving cold and warm fronts, which are the outcome of uneven heating of the earth's surface by the sun. We know the earth's surface is heated unevenly, so how can we expect the winds caused by this to be even? A variance in the speed of wind by ten percent can change the turbine power by twenty-five percent. This makes wind power unreliable. Today's consumers are accustomed to reliable energy sources, and the fickleness of wind cannot satisfy those demands. Another argument against wind power is the effect of wind farms on the surrounding area. "Planting" wind farms uses land that could be used for agriculture or urban/suburban development. Also, migrating birds are endangered by the turbines, because they may be struck by the windmill blades. In addition, the noise pollution from a turbine is close to that of a small jet engine, which may frighten the wildlife in the vicinity, and will definitely disturb any humans living nearby. Add to all of this the degradation of the aesthetic value of the land. The turbines' design is seen as ugly by many, and wind farms take beautiful, natural landscapes and make them into dull and drear views of mechanical objects.

label: TRAINING
data_answer: Many advocates of wind energy ignore, sometimes deliberately, the plethora of disadvantages of this emerging technology, including but not limited to: limited efficiency; aesthetical damage; and danger posed to wildlife, the ecosystem, and the environment. The principal argument negating the benefits of this new source of energy is the limited efficiency of the turbines themselves. Wind energy, of course, requires wind, without which turbines cannot generate energy; however, there is no location where the wind blows all day, everyday, thus producing energy 24/7, the first of many issues negatively affecting energy output. Furthermore, maximum efficiency would be reached where there are little or no wind obstructions - for example, forests, mountains, and man-made structures - but there are few such ideal spots, thus decreasing efficiency again. Even in chronically windy locations, wind speed varies by 10%, which equates to a 25% variation in turbine power. When taking the extremely limited efficiency of wind turbines into account with production costs, even advocates must acknowledge the foolishness of attempting this venture on a grand scale. There are, no doubt, a few locations ideal for wind turbines, but by definition they must be located somewhere distant from urban developments or civilization, in remote regions with not only no man-made structures, but no obstructing, naturally-ocurring geographic obstructions as well. This immediately increases production and development costs, which can be compounded with the cost of maintainence. The turbines must be continuously replaced or repaired due to damage inflicted by nature, especially lightning. Thus the output, energy, is not worth the input, money and resources. Efficiency aside, these turbines have a significant impact on the environment as well. Although the most appealing benefit of wind energy is its supposedly low impact on the Earth, this belief is ill-founded. Although there may be a limited carbon footprint, in its stead, there is a significant ecosystem impact; the turbines, placed in remote locations with plentiful wildlife, endanger wildlife, especially migrating birds. This is worrisome because of the already diminishing wildlife diversity because of humans' impact. Furthermore, they create significant noise pollution, and unnecessarily blemish what remaining testiments exist of Earth's former glory. Thus, overall, wind energy in theory has its merits, but the complications that accompany real-world scenarios clearly negate any and all benefits of this budding technology.

label: TRAINING
data_answer: Wind energy, while a relatively eco-friendly and convenient source of power, has several important flaws. The turbines that generate wind energy rely, obviously, on wind, and because wind does not blow constantly, the turbines cannot generate energy reliably. This is similar to the effect of solar panels, which can only generate energy during the day. Wind speed and turbine power vary as well, by 10% and 25%, respectively. Furthemore, wind can be obstructed by forests, mountains, buildings, and other man-made structures, exacerbating the unreliability of wind and therefore wind energy. Turbines have a high likelihood of being struck by lightning, due to their height and metallic composition, creating damage and costly repairs. Turbines are also rather large machines, and since they are often placed in remote or rural areas, their noisy blades and incongruity with a natural setting can ruin a landscape. Though wind energy is often hailed as a "green" and non-polluting source of energy, turbines' spinning blades are a danger to migrating birds and their placement in a natural habitat may be detrimental to endangered species living in the area. They can also be unpleasant for any humans living nearby, as turbines create significant noise pollution and groups of them in wind farms can create the volume of a small jet engine. Clearly, wind energy is an imperfect source of electricity, and its disadvantages may very well outweigh its advantages.

label: TRAINING
data_answer: Although wind energy is believed to be the next innovative way in obtaining energy efficiently, wind energy has drawbacks that neutralize the andvantages. For one, the use of windmills can be detrimental to numerous types of wildlife, especially birds migrating in the winter. The inconsistencies in wind speed and turbine power also create an unpredictable source of power that can produce sufficient energy, and insufficient energy at times. These turbines can also be prone to environmental disasters such as lightning, earthquakes and tornadoes. The wildlife in areas of windmills can be harmed significantly. Animals that get too close to these windmills, primarily birds, can be absolutely shredded and killed by these blades. The noise that windmills generate can also disrupt the lives of animals and prove to be harmul to their health. The inconsistencies that these windmills have can also prove to be a major problem. With wind speed varying by 10% (a very significant variable), the amount of energy produced can prove to be insufficient at times, especially when supplying a heavily populated city. Coupled with the varying turbine power (25%), this can be a very risky proposition, especially for densily populated cities. The noise pollution can prove to be a very dangerous problem for wildlife as well. The noise generated by these windmills can disrupt the habitats of many animals. This could also affect their circadian rhythms and biological clocks, changing their behavior, which could make them more or less hostile.

label: TRAINING
data_answer: Wind energy, while seemingly an ideal source for alternative energy, is not as perfect as one might believe. Wind energy has been used throughout history, allowing for ample amounts of data to be retrieved on the defecits of it. It can create large numbers of distractions for a society that harnesses the power of the wind. The wind energy can also create a surprising amount of damage to the environment, contradictory to a piece of the glamour of alternative energy. Wind energy is a hassle for a society to accept into its life due to its many shortcomings and distractions it provides for society. Since wind energy relies on being able to harness the power of the wind at all times to function properly, there is a significant lack of power when the wind stops blowing. In many climates there is a lack of wind flow, making the alternative energy of wind power virtually useless there. Along with the lack of function when wind fails to blow, there is a variance in the wind speed in an area, leading to a variance in the amount of power that can be provided to a society attempting to function with wind power. The wind power can also fail to function if the turbine suffers from lightning damage, requiring a repair to occur lest the society wish for less power. Wind power also suffers from the problem of having a far-reaching negative effect on the environment around. The wind turbines contrast the beautiful landscape of the natural environment and can even obstruct the road to natural and artificial landmarks, creating an incovenience for the society it supposedly benefits. the wind farms that would be necessary to power a whole town would escalate these problems and cause huge annoyances due to the excessive noise levels. Along with the irritating, but truthfully small, problems, wind power could cause a huge problem for the wildlife. The blades on the windmills could cause a serious hazard to any bird populations around the area or any migrating birds that happen to be travelling by. With an artifical creation so hazardous, it would not be easy for the birds to avoid this potential damage, leading to a decline in the avian populations, leaving more indentations in the natural ecosystem caused by humanity.

data_answer: Although many people think wind energy is effective, useful, and cheap, there is also downsides to the use of wind turbines. Wind turbines are not always going to blow, they need wind speed to pick them up so, if there is no wind they will not turn. All in all, the disadvantage of wind energy outweight the advantages, and thus should be the reason why wind energy should not be relied on in society.

On top of all that, turbines are dangerous to the avian species that might fly into them, which include many species of migrating birds and endangered wildlife. Lastly, the turbines themselves are not safe from damage; lightning strikes can damage the blades and render the wind farm unusable.

label: TRAINING
data_answer: Using windmills to create electricity is not a new technoloy. However, modern methods of creating power through turbines proves to have several drawbacks when considering environmental reprecussions. As a result, utilizing wind energy as a source of electricity is a poor use of rural land. The emerging technology of electricity-generating windmills involve a massive set of blades, much like wings, that can cause damage to the environment and impact scenery. A large amount of space is required in order to construct a wind farm in the first place, as any obstructions entirely sabotage the construction of wind turbines. Construction of modern wind turbines also ruin the aesthetic of rural areas due to their unappealing, large design. These huge blades generate electricity, but they also generate deafening amounts of noise, disturbing the relative peace of the environment. The turbines themselves also cause noise pollution that further disturbs the surroundings. In addition, the spinning blades endager migrating birds and other animals, due to the turbine possibly interrupting migration by colliding with airborne animals. Efficiency of wind power must also be taken into account, as many characteristics of wind power leave it liable to failure. Wind does not blow all the time, as weather dictates, and thus a sustainable amount of electricity might not be generated. Turbine power also varies by 25%, in comparision to wind speed, which varies by 10%. Lightning can easily strike turbines down and prevent smooth functioning, further hampering wind turbine efficiency.

data_answer: Wind turbines are unreliable sources of energy. Although they do not create waste, they accessibility and usage of these wind turbines is not constant, and therefore cannot be counted on as a strong, reliable source. Wind occurs naturally, and will not always be blowing, so the energy guaranteed depends on the weather, which is constantly changing. Wind turbines cannot be built in any given area, they require an open area with high winds, and can be obstructed by such abundantly occuring objects as forests, mountains, buildings, and any other structures which could block the natural flow of wind. Also, wind turbines are ugly, making them stand out in the natural settings where they are placed. They can obstruct the migration patterns of birds and other wildlife. The disadvantages of wind power far outweigh the advantages, and we are better off using other, more reliable forms of energy.

label: TRAINING
data_answer: While wind energy may be cost-effective, any benifits are far outweighed by the numerous issues with this outdated technology. Harnessing the wind to generate energys may have been a viable option a hundred or more years ago, when energy production methods such as nucleur power were still extremely underdeveloped or not even concieved of yet. However, in this day and age wind energy proves to be uneffective and unreliable. The main issue with wind energy is that it is not something that can be controlled, as the wind obviously does not blow every hour of every day of every year. Other technologies like nucleur power can be controlled, and can be harnessed at any time as long as the plant is operational. This lack of control results in an unsteady flow sof electricity, and is possible of failing when it is needed the most. Another issue is the environmental impact. While many lobbyists for wind energy may argue that it has very little or no impact on the environment, this is not true. They are large and bulky, capable of disturbing the natural environment of an organism. The spinning blades that generate the energy are also a large hazard. Any animal unlucky enough to fly through one of the turbines will have absolutely no chance of surviving, and this can be very dangerous for large migratory groups, especially when the area has many turbines present. Somewhat less negative are the aesthetic effect, or lack thereof, of the turbines. Designs for these machines are often as utilitarian as possible, sacrificing any pleasing design for the most energy that can possibly be produced. When large numbers of these ugly devices are set togethor, on what is called a wind farm, they often completely ruin the natural beauty of the location. Even if they somehow fit in with the locale, the noise they produce is bad enough, equivalent to a small jet engine. Combined with their environmental detriments, the many negative aspects of wind turbines render them an unprefferable choice for our evolving energy technology.

label: TRAINING
data_answer: Wind energy, like other new types of renewable energy, has captured the attention of envinronmentalists and electricity consumers. As a clean and renewable energy, wind energy certainly creates less pollution and is more sustainable than other forms of energy like coal, natural gas or oil. However, although wind energy becomes more and more important for a green society, there are some disadvantages of wind energy we must consider before we use it in our daily life. First of all, wind--especially high-speed wind--does not exist everywhere. Wind is only abundant in certain areas such as shoreline, the top of a hill, or an open empty space. High-speed wind rarely exists in densely-populated areas such as the cities and suburbs. That being said, wind energy must be first transported hundreds of miles to our homes before we use it. Therefore, a certain amount of energy will be wasted during the process of transportation. Similarly, wind does not always blow continuously at the same speed. If wind energy is not sufficient enough to provide energy at any hour of the day, then it would be a hugh issue when people are in a desparate need of electricity. On the other hand, wind energy is not 100% eco-friendly. The size of those turbines that are used to generate wind energy is enormous. The momentum of the turbines can kill hundreds of birds that accidentally fly through. At the same time, since these turbines are mostly constructed in the nature, they might be obstructions or even the damage to the environment. Turbines might take the place of the habitats of some animals. Therefore, wildlifes could be potentially endangered. As a result, wind energy should be given enough thoughts and be well-developed before its actual application.

label: TRAINING
data_answer: However, there are several reasons why wind power can be deterimental. The wind doesn't blow with the consistency required for a stable power source. Even when the wind is blowing, the speed can vary by as much as 10%, which results in turbine power varying by a quarter. The turbines also create a lot of irritating noise, with larger wind farms being as potentially loud as a jet engine. The shape of the wind mill can also act as a giant lightning rod in the middle of an open area. Lightning striking the wind mill could have disasterous, costly effects. Wind mills are also difficult to place. In larger cities, structures such as skyscrapers or other buildings obstruct the wind. On the other hand, in rural areas, the striking contrast between the tall, rigid form of the wind mill and the serenity of the natural landscape is ruinous, aesthetically. The only other option would be to put wind mills in smaller cities, but the intensity of the noise pollution would mean a strong public united against the idea. The wind mills can also be harmful, if not lethal, to endangered wildlife, such as migrating birds.

data_answer: Wind turbines, although they can provide some benefits, are noisy, finicky annoyances that often ruin the landscape of a given area. The mere function of a wind turbine exudes the sound and volume of a jet engine, disturbing wildlife and human occupants alike. Aside from noise pollution, wind turbines also often contradict the rural setting they must be placed in, and obstruct any chance for consistancy in a given location. Wind turbines also require extremely specific conditions to operate at optimal capacity: the surrounding landscape must be virtually barren of obstructions, and even then, wind is never constant in any location. There is also the issue of weather variance. Wind turbines are too cumbersome to relocate in the event of a large storm, and the required conditions for efficient functionality of wind turbines leaves them exposed to the elements. Although they can be cleaner and cheaper than other energy sources, wind turbines are for too fickle and obtuse to be utilized on a large scale.

data_answer: With the rise of the global warming epidemic across the globe, people everywhere are looking for ways to reduce their carbon footprint. One of the major ways society can create this change is through the production of clean energy. Rather than burning carbon fuels and releasing gasses into the atmosphere that destroy or ozone layer, we have found ways to harvest energy from the forces of nature. A seemingly popular method to harness this energy is through windmills. However, the reality of the implementations of the windmill is not all that it is chalked up to be. There are multiple defects to the windmill. The major flaw in this design is that wind is not a constant force. It varies greatly with weather patterns, and does not even always blow in the same direction. Even if it is the windiest day of the year, if the wind is not hitting your windmill head on then the amount of energy absorbed will be greatly reduced. Not only is the windmill unreliable, it de-beautifies nature and our communties. When the blades do catch the wind, they tend to make a lot of noise. No one wants to plant a big and ugly windmill in their front yard that will create constant noise pollution along with damaging the image of their house.

data_answer: Wind Energy has often been refered to as a clean, efficient, and and cost effective source in terms of energy generation; however, despite the source being less costly than those of coal and oil, there are in truth several disadvantages, especially its effects on the landscape, and nature itself. The primary use of windmills is to generate energy, and many claim that it is an extremely effective source; it may be at times, however the wind does not blow every hour of the day, and its speed varies by 10%, while the turbine power varies by 25%. In addition to its inconsistent effectiveness, the blades themselves have been known to be very noisy, and the turbines are far too large with an unappealing design which ruins the image of the rural landscape. Aside from the image of windmills as well as their effectiveness, the usage of Wind Energy has several faults by its effects upon nature as well as nature's effects upon itself. Due to the large sturcuture of windmills as well as their placement in high altitudes, windmills have recieved turbine lightning damage, which may or may not greatly effect their cost for repair and efficiency. It has also been noted that they have endagered wildlife especially those of migrating birds, that may be obstructed by the large turbines.

data_answer: Although wind power has recieved much praise it isn't quite the miracle many have made it out to be. Just as any other source of energy, wind energy comes with a price to pay. For example, they aren't as transparant as one might have been led to think. They're large structures that require excessive space. Wind power is also unreliable, as the speed and direction the wind blows is unpredictable. These are only two examples and they're just scratching the surface! Windmills used to produce wind energy are poorly engineered and unconventional. Weather-wind especially- is an unpredictable thing. The speed of the wind significantly varies the speed in which the turbine's blades rotate, altering the amount of energy able to be produced. Even more problematic is the case of no wind at all-no power! Sometimes, during heavy storms, a turbine may be struck by lightening, cause damage to the machine. Wind turbines need to be erected in large grids to produce a profitable amount of energy, meaning they consume quite a bit of land. Windmills require land without any obstructions(often natural, preserved land) to achieve maximum exposure to wind. Ironically, the large, unsightly turbines become an obstruction themselves. They taint rural landscapes with their industrial and out-of-place structures.Wind power also isn't as innocent as it's often portrayed. Surprisingly, it does produce pollution-noise pollution, that is. A grid of turbines may generate an equivalent amount of noise as a small jet engine. The destruction of wind energy doesn't stop their either. Tall, closely aranged windmills present a tremendous hazard to any creatures in the sky, particularly migratory birds.

data_answer: While there are clear benefits to wind power over other sources of energy, the drawbacks far outweigh the advantages. Wind, while renewable, is not reliable. Wind does not blow every hour of everyday as coal burns. This could create droughts of electricity when there is no wind. Looking further into wind fluctuations, the gearing inside the windmill creates an effect which multiplies any drop in wind speed. For example, if the wind speed drops by 10% there will be a 25% drop in electrical output. This further eccentuates the problems with an inconsistent breeze. Many green energy advocates say that these windmills will help the environment, however, the mills are actually a nuscience. The wind turbines are big ugly masses that asthetically pollute the rural landscape. They cannot be built anywhere near any buildings, mountains, etc. Another consideration is the offensive noise of the monstrosities. They create a noise akin to that of a small jet engine which takes away the tranquility of rural landscape. These mills are not even designed to withstand lightening which is very common in most windy areas. While considered a practical, green solution to the energy crisis, windmills actually are an impractical stain on rural beauty. The mills even kill migrating birds, how is that an environmentally friendly solution?

data_answer: Wind energy may be a very good source of clean, renewable energy, but there are many flaws to this energy source. This includes the effect on the environment and the unreliability of this source of power. Wind power uses giant turbines in order to generate enough electricity to power several homes. These turbines are noisy, contributing to sound pollution to the point of being comparable to a small jet engine running constantly. It also obstructs the view as well as the potential flight patterns of migrating birds. This can cause the deaths of many birds, which in turn could contribute to an imbalance in the ecosystem. Not only is this source of power disruptive to the lives of people and animals, but it is also an unreliable source of power. Unlike renewable power sources such as geothermal heating, wind power is extremely unreliable. Depending on the weather, these turbines could get no wind for several days on end. If we switched to just wind power, many homes could be without power for a long time. The turbines also have the large potential of conducting electricity, specifically lightning strikes. This would cause damage to the turbines, making them unsafe to work on or be around.

The wind turbines also have alot of noise and cause noise pollution because of their small jet engine it uses to help turn the heavy blades and produce electricity. With as many as there are in a field, it can cause alot of unwanted and disturbing noise. The turbines also ruin the landscape because people either destroy the landscape to make room, or they put them in an open landscape and plague it's look with modern day technologies. They can also be danger to the environment around them because of their huge blades. If put near a tree, mountain, or building the blade can hit the top of the tree, side of the mountain, or the top of the building and destroy the turbine, the object it came in contact with, or both. The wind speed varies by 10% while the turbine power varies by 25%. This means that it takes more electricity to run than it does the generate which is not effcient at all. Since the turbines are so big, they can also endanger wildlife as well, especially birds. As the birds are flying they can come in contact with the blades and fall to the ground, killing them when they land, if not when they hit the blade. the blades may not move very fast but if something hits the blade or the trunk, the turbine is probably not going to budge or be damaged. Lightning can also strike the turbine and cause some serious damage to the turbine and even the environment around it. Because the turbine is all metal, when lightning strikes it, the lightning will travel through the turbine and in the ground and probably shortciurcut or blow up the whole structure.

label: TRAINING
data_answer: Wind energy may be a source of renewable energy. It may be an efficient power source to execute farming, pumping water and work sawmills; and they do work great in rural areas. But even with several green benefits, there are still spots in wind energy that just is not consistent. Windmill blades can create electric energy when in a windy enviornment but this obviously relies on how windy it is. Without wind blowing 24/7, the windmills are virtually useless. Even if there is wind blowing there are still percentage statistics that downgrade wind power efficiency. The average wind speed varies by 10%, so no fault goes to the consistency of wind; most of what you get is constant depending on the area. The efficiency problem lies in the windmill itself. People can not exactly be sure if what they see in efficiency is what they will get. When given wind there will be times when windmills will give you an abundance of energy. But the amount of energy can vary by as much as 25%. In addition to efficiency there is always the concern of safety for the windmill's enviornment. The giant blades can pose as a great danger for ongoing birds. Birds are mainly the animal at risk, as they could very well be injured or killed if flying too close to windmills. And with being at such a high point, the turbines could easily attract lightning during a storm. If lightning strikes there will likely not be many humans directly affected by it. But if the turbines are close to a wooded area or forests, then it can start a forestfire dealing massive damage to the enviornment. When looking at the downsides of wind energy it may be a better idea to look into other renewable energy sources before committing to wind energy.

label: TRAINING
data_answer: Wind energy, although thought to be an ideal solution to the world's persistent search for energy, also has numerous disadvantages in the form of external forces. Wind energy comes from windmills, which theoretically can blow 24/7 during "hurricanes, power outages, or brown outs", but in reality windmills still face weather issues such as turbine lightning damage. Windmills also face obstructions such as forests, mountains, buildings, and other structures, which hinder their sails from turning to create wind energy. Wind energy, produced by windmills and windfarms, is able to harm the environment through noise pollution, and endangering wildlife. In order to create wind energy, windmill blades must cut through the air to turn an electric generator. This motion causes the blades to create noise tantamount to that of a small jet engine. In addition to noise pollution, windmills can endanger natural species, such as birds. Birds may fly near windmills, only to get struck down and injured or worse die. Therefore, although wind energy seems like a perfect green energy source, it has many problems due to external conditions it faces, and the noise pollution and endangerment of wildlife it creates.

data_answer: In regards to the growing controversy in regards to green energy, Wind energy has risen as a potential green energy source that could harbour electricity for a large amount of the U.S population. Although the benefits of Wind energy are extremely promising, many indivduals fail to realize the disadvantages that come with building wind turbines. By building massive amounts of wind turbines in order to provide electricity, there would be obstructions to nature and wildlife. Furthermore, wind is not an absolute source of energy and can cause noise pollution in the environnment. It is clear that although wind energy does hold potential it still negatively affects nature and animals for the sake for more electricity. Building wind mills is a grueling task and in conclusion it takes up a lot of space. In order to achieve the required amount of electricity to provide for the whole U.S population, a massive amounts of land would have to be sacrificed. In doing so, more harm would be caused to the environnment which is the opposite of what "green energy" is trying to accomplish. Sacrificinng precious land and forests filled with tress and wildlife would be a step backwards in sustaning the ever so fragile enviornment. Furthermore, wind mills would negatively affect many wildlifes such as birds by disrupting the flow of migrating birds. This would lead to a domino effect in which the whole ecosystem may be harmed. The loud noises that are caused due to the windmills would further hinder other wildlife and interupt with the flow of nature. Also, since it causes so much noise, it would not be wise to install windmills in homes as it would disturb other residents. It is clear that, although wind energy is seen as a benefit towards the enviornment, in reality it may do more harm than good. The massive amounts of land and disturbance that it causes simply isn't worth the extra 3% of electricty when it is harming our ecosystem and threatning wildlife.

Wind turbines should not be used as a primary source of power, as there are to many conditions that have to be met for them to be effective. Such as the unreliablillity of a constant wind source, or the fact of a fire hazard during storms that might have lightning. Not only do wind turbines pose a problem in these aspects, but they might also negatively affect the bird populations, as they migrate south for the winter. In consession wind energy, is infact a clean energy source, and are rather cost effective for their intended usages. label: TRAINING
data_answer: While wind farms may seem like the perfect solution to the world's energy crisis, they are extremely impractical in most areas. The windmills used to generate wind energy are bulky and ugly; they can ruin the beauty of a rural landscape, and send property values plummeting as they do. In addition to their unsightliness, these turbines are LOUD--about the decibel level of a small jet engine. Most people don't want to live near windfarms due to their unattractive and noisy disruption. In addition, many remote areas are not viable options for wind farms. Any large obstructions, including forests and mountains, will interfere with airflow and render wind energy ineffective. Also, an area has to be very windy for most of the year in order for wind energy to be useful--a decrease in wind speed of only 10% will decrease the amount of power generated by about 25%. In addition to their impracticality, wind farms are not nearly as "green" as most people assume. Despite the fact that they don't generate any fuel or radioactive waste, windmills still have a negative impact on the environment. The large structures create a great deal of noise, disrupting the natural landscapes in which they are so often placed. The windmills can attract lightning strikes, which sometimes cause fires. Also, the turbine blades kill migrating birds, including many endangered species. Overall, despite their advantages, wind farms are too impractical--and too dangerous--to become a major energy source for Americans.

label: TRAINING
data_answer: After looking at the advantages of Wind Energy, one can see that it is actually a fairly good idea, but there are many more disadvantages than one might think. Using Wind Energy is overall, more trouble than it's worth. Windmills generate electricity or power through blades, which like airplane wings, are lifted by air flow, which causes them to rotate. The rotation of the blades is connected to a drive shaft which causees an electric generator to turn and creates electricity. Although people across America have used windmills for centuries, there have always been many problems with it's use. Wind is not very reliable, meaning it doesn't blow all the time. If the wind doesn't constantly blow, they will need to have larger and faster gusts of wind in order to make up for the time that the generators aren't producing electricity. As well as being unreliable, it's loud. the blades make sounds that are not something one wants to hear all the time. The noise may also disrupt wildlife habitats and cause changes in where birds and other animals make their homes in certain seasons. The turbines may also cause harmful changes to the migrating patterns of birds and could also be detrimental to endangered species. To add to the list, windmills are an eyesore. These oversized turbines disrupt the landscape, they are ugly in design and ruin the pure look of the land. No one driving through practically untouched land, full of grace and beauty, wants to see big, clunky windmills overcrowding and invading the peace of the rural landscape. Windmills may be efficient and don't produce detrimental wastes, but they aren't worth the time or money to put up. They are more of a liability than an asset and cause many hazards and problems. The negative effects outweigh the positive in this case and no matter how many good things it has, there are always the bad things, which are greater, to ruin it all.

data_answer: The use of wind energy comes with many disadvantages that make it an undesirable choice such as the unreliability of wind, the endangering of wildlife, and the possiblity of wind turbines getting damaged by lightning. Even though society makes vast strides in weather-detecting technology every year, we still do not have the ability to tell how often the wind will blow in the next several years. As such, there lies a possibility that the government could spend millions of dollars on wind farms only for there to exist no wind for a majority of the time. Also, if we started to rely on wind power more heavily then there would be consequenses for a lack of wind like blackouts or power failures. The endangering of wildlife brings the second disadvantage. Wind turbines create quite a danger when one truly thinks about it. Large portions of migrating bird flocks could recieve injury or death from flying into turbines. The possibility of wind turbines getting damaged by lighting brings the third disadvantage. Wind turbines, usually made of metal, could easily act as giant lightning rods. The lightning strikes would damage the turbines if not flat out destroy them, making them needed to be fixed or unusable.

data_answer: The student is very correct in saying that the wind does not blow all day, every day. The only problem with wind energy is the variation in wind speed and the time that the wind blows. Yes, it is completely clean, and renewable, but it is not consistent. If all of America was run on Wind Turbines, we would experience massive blackouts during down times, because the wind doesn't always blow. We cannot rely solely on Wind, but it can be used to supplement other sources during peak times, or times when energy consumption is high. So say at night, when homes are using a lot of electricity because people are cooking dinner, and watching TV; if the wind is blowing steadily, power companies will turn of coal generators, or diesel generators, or nuclear stations. I feel like the most consistent form of power we could have, is hydroelectric. But not the current hydro, the new age hydro. Where you put a horizontal turbine on the shore of a body of water, and let the tide spin the turbine. This is the most consistent, because the tides don't stop, and they are always going. 24/7. It is clean, and the only environment impact is possible relocation of aquatic life.

label: TRAINING
data_answer: While wind energy offers many of the above mentioned benefits, it should also be mentioned that generating wind energy is much more noisy and unreliable than coal or nuclear powered. The large wind turbines not only stick out like a sore thumb in the countryside, but produce quite a bit of noise pollution-- as much as a small jet engine. Wind power is also not viable in anywhere that doesn't have large clearings available. Forests and urban areas provide almost no space for wind turbines, while solar panels can be place on roofing almost anywhere. Being dependent on the weather also makes wind power rather unreliable, and almost useless in areas with little weather, such as deserts. Finally, the potential for damage caused by weather is very high with wind power. Wind turbines are essentially tall metal rods hundreds of feet high. It is very likely for a turbine to be struck by lightning during a storm.

label: TRAINING
data_answer: Windmills, despite their many pros, are not always reliable. There are many places with no wind, and wind turbines would not function there reliably. They would create sporatic amounts of energy, which would make it very difficult for people to power their homes and their heat or air conditioning with wind power. In addition, the wind speed varies by 10%, which makes the power of the turbines vary by 25%. This is a big discrepancy -- some people might get really strong power sources from strong winds, but as the wind changes, those power levels may drop suddenly or disappear altogther. And for every person with an abundance of wind power, there will be people on the opposite end of the scale, whose wind power is never strong enough. The big variant in the turbine power would also make it difficult to create a generator to fit both the upper end and the lower end of the scale. Because of the unreliability of wind, windmills are not a viable source of energy. Windmills are also noisy and considered ugly by many people. The blades make a lot of noise, and wind farms sound like a small jet engine. This can create a distraction or an annoyance for many people. Constantly hearing the sound of blades swishing through the air can get frustrating, or give someone a headache. But beyond just the noise they make, people think windmills are ruining the landscape. They claim the turbines are too big and an ugly design, and the rural landscape is ruined by adding windmills in. Along with that comes the environmental factor. In order to build the windmills, lots of trees have to be cut down. Opponents of windmills would argue that this is bad for the environment and effectively cancels out the energy-saving abilities of the turbines. In the process of building, animals are also killed as their habitats are destroyed, and once the windmills are up and running, it is likely that many birds will die from flying too close to the blades. This is an unnecessary cause of many deaths. Because of the flaws in their design, wind turbines have many disadvantages.

By building turbines, it will cost a lot of money for cities. It will cause them to have to destroy a building in order to save money. Turbines can cause lots of obstructions to forests and mountains. In order to build them they would have to take down lots of trees and that destroys a lot of animal habitats. Since wind speed varies, it would mean that the turbines would be working efficiently on different days meaning that on some days they would produce more electricity than on other days. Since turbines are built tall, they can be more likely to be hit by lightning, which causes lots of damage. label: VALIDATION
data_answer: Wind energy does present some formidable setbacks regarding its efficiency, possibility of failure, and negative impact on the environment. The productivity of windmills can vary greatly, as most windmills will not run continuously throughout any given day, as well as the fact that wind speed can vary by as much as ten percent and turbine power can vary within a margin of twenty-five percent. The need for space can also inhibit windmills' efficiency due to the fact that the large tracts of land required to develop sizeable wind farms are quite often obstructed by forests, mountains, and man-made establishments. Windmills are further questionable in their reliability as functioning machines. Turbines can undergo severe damage from storms (some have undergone reported lightning damage) and flocks of migrating birds, both of which can cost thousands of dollars in repair for the turbine. As far as endangering the environment is concerned, besides the aforementioned killing of birds, windmills are an aesthetic disruption of the peaceful serenity of many picturesque landscapes and transmit bothersome noise pollution, similar to that of a small jet flying overhead, across wind farms and their surrounding areas.

label: VALIDATION
data_answer: Wind energy is not an ideal form of energy because of its unreliability. Wind does not blow 100% of the time, meaning users would also have to draw energy from a backup source or risk going without power when the wind dies down. This could be devastating for places such as hospitals and airports, whose continued functionality is vital for safety reasons. Also, wind speeds are not always consistent. They can vary by a margin of 10%, which can cause power fluctuations of up to 25%. In order to supply necessary power reliably, only 75% of the wind farm's could be counted on, whch means the possible 25% extra power would be wasted or need to be diverted or stored, another hastle. One more important factor is the necessary elements needed for a wind farm. Cities, for instance, do not have space for massive turbines, which means they would have to be constructed outside of the city. This would waste money on extra power cables to run the power into towns. If the clients of electrical companies want renewable energy, solar power would make an ideal substitute in this case, becasue solar pannels can be mounted on the tops of skyscrapers. For these reasons, wind energy is an unreliable source of power.

data_answer: Although Wind Energy seems to be more advanageous than other types of energy, it has some disadvantages. For example, when relying on wind as a resource for energy, there mus be some wind at all times. However, this is not true. Wind does not blow all 24 hours of a day 7 days a week. This means that there must be some way to store the energy, otherwise, we can't expect energy all the time. Furthermore, obstructions, such as forests, mountains, building, and oher man-made structures prevent wind from traveling, thus preventing energy from being created. The turbine would have to be placed in an open field for there to be as much wind as possible. Additionaly, wind power is unsafe for endangered wildlife. migrating birds might get hit by the turbine, causing a domino effect. The impact of the bird hitting the turbine might cause a disruptance in the balance of it, causing it to turn unsafely, thus causing it to break and hurt the surrounding wildlife. Clearly, Wind Power has its flaws and needs to be perfected more.

data_answer: While windmills may be a useful source of renewable energy, its drawbacks are great in both number and severity. One of the windmills more praised features is it's lack of ability to create pollution, as all it needs in order to generate electricity is wind. The pollution created is of a less conventional sort, that of sight and sound. Wind farms have been compared to sounding like a small jet engine, and the optimal locations for these farms, at the top of hills and ridges, are also the optimal locations to destroy any natural beauty a landscape may have. Which leads into it's second downfall, it's unreliability. Wind mills create electricity by harnessing the power of the wind, wind that does not blow at a constant rate, nor in a constant direction. Therefor, windmills cannot supply a constant stream of energy. On the subject of unreliability, windmills not only have an unreliable power source, but are unreliable themselves, having a power output that varies by at least 25% when the wind only varies 15%.

label: VALIDATION
data_answer: Wind energy, despite being significantly more enviromentally friendly than the metric tons of oil and fossil fuels drilled from the earth, is not a be-all, end-all energy source. The problem with wind-based electricity is that it is not reliable and stable. There is no one place where the winds blow all the time from dawn to dusk, meaning that energy generated can vary from day to day. Also, the turbines can be obstructed by various factors, depending on the area. Forests, mountains, buildings, these things can get in the way and reduce the effieciency of the wind turbines. The wind turbine is not the most aesthetically appealing, either. The turbines tend to have a large design, built for maximum efficiency. The problem is that this creates an almost obnoxious contrast with the rural landscapes where these are generally found, and the turbines contain a small but noisy jet engine that creates more noise. This noise is as erious issue in rural areas, and the noise can ruin the ecosystem by scaring off birds and animals. Wind turbines might be a solution to fossil fuels and climate change, but then they become a completely different problem. The turbine become a potential safety hazard to various parts of the ecosystem. Birds don't always pay attention when they fly, so they might not see the incoming, several inch thick blade bearing down on their body. So aside from the noise pollution, now ther is a safety hazard for wildlife, especially where there are endangered bird species. Moreover, turbines aren't built to deal with lightning storms, so when they do strike, the turbine can break down, requiring a good deal of time and money to repair. Worse, they fall over, becoming the equivalent of downed power line, dangerous to both people and fauna, with the additional risk of causing a fire, especially where there tends to be fairly little rain and lots of dry grass. Wind power is a much better alternative to fossil fuels compared to, say, nuclear fusion, but there's too many risks and problems to put a wind farm on every acre of land

label: VALIDATION
data_answer: Over the last several decades, wind energy has been expanded as a source of energy in many countries. This expansion has been welcomed by many as an important innovation in sustainable energy. However, we must all ask ourselves: "are these windmills really as fantastic as we are all led to believe?". The answer to this question may surprise many as there are several lesser known factors that make wind energy more of a liability than an asset for the world many wish for it to support. Fisrt of all, these wind turbines are detremental to bird population. This point should seem obvious as a bird can hardly be expected to navigate a field of what can sometimes be hundreds of wind turbines and emerge unhamed on the other side. This could create more endangered birds in a world where wildlife is already struggling, or worse, drive already endangered species' closer to, or even completely to, extinction. This brings up the point of the greater inefficiency of wind turbines. When birds hit the such turbines, it may damage the turbine as well causing a need for constant maintainance. When added to the danger of lightning damage, and the difficulties of finding an unemcumbered area large enough for an amount of turbines to generate any worthwhile amount of energy, it becomes evident that wind energy is more trouble than it's worth. Finally, it should be mentioned that, not only is wind energy dangerous to bird populations and considerably inefficient, but it also causes for the people living in the rural areas where the turbines are located. For example, the enourmous blades used to generate the energy may also generate an intollerable amount of noise for the local population. This is additionally hindering when considering that the turbines also double as big, ugly poles that ruin an otherwise pristine rural landscape. As one can infer from these arguments, wind energy, while a nice idea, is far from being the green dream many envision it to be.

data_answer: Wind Energy, although it may have its advantages, is not the best of choices for renewable energy. There are too many variables when it comes to how much energy it will produce. label: VALIDATION
data_answer: Although wind turbines may be a greener energy source, there are problems that will make wind power ineffective. First, the weather is unpredictable. Wind may not blow 24/7. There will be times when the wind will not be able to blow. If there is no wind, then there is no power. Also, the wind speed varies between each day. The wind speed varies by 10%, which causes turbine power to vary by 25%. So one day the wind will be blowing very hard and fast, but the next day, the wind may not blow that hard. That means that one day, a town may have an abundance of electricity, but the next day, they may not have enough to power everything that reqiures electricity. Next, wind turbines have noisy blades that can cause noise pollution if there is enough of them. In fact, wind farms generate enough noise equivalent to a small jet engine. That will make it harder for residents to perform activities that require a quite setting. Lastly, wind turbines can be a danger to the enviroment. The turbines are too big, they have an ugly design, and they ruin rural landscape. Since the wind is more powerful at greater heights, the wind turbines need to be tall to recieve as much wind power as possible. Because of this, animals such as birds are risk of rinning into the turbine blades and dying. Also, the turbines can act as a lightning rod during thunder storms. This can also danger wildlife that live close to wind farms. With these problems concerning wind turbines, I believe we should just stick to what we have been using to generate our electricity.

label: VALIDATION
data_answer: Although wind farms may seem like a great idea, there are several key disadvantages. First of all, while the sun shines consistently every day and crude oil imports are scheduled, wind flow is unpredictable without advanced weather instruments. Thus, there may be periods of "wind droughts" when a reigon experiences no wind. For those small communities that place their dependence completely on wind power, they might experience long periods of power outages that cripples them. Another key disadvantage to wind power is pollution. In the traditional sense, pollution is mainly associated with carbon dioxide exhaust or toxic waste. Using this outdated definition, some proponents for wind farms claim that wind power produces no pollution. They, however, overlook noise pollution. The noise produced from a wind farm rivals that of a small jet engine. Like CO2 emissions or toxic waste, noise pollution distrubs the sourrounding environment of the wind farm and has detrimental effects on the wildlife there, many of which rely on their sense of hearing to survive. Thus, while wind power does carry advantages, it also has significant setbacks.

They stand out and ruin the design of thier setting. They are inconsistant as well. As the wind speed varies by ten percent, turbine power varies twenty five percent. This means that if the wind speed slightly changes, the turbine looses a quarter of its power. Finally, the turbines are a danger to wildlife, especially migrating birds. Not only are they able to slice many birds up, but they also change the wind pattern which can really affect the bird while migrating. It is clear that there are more sufficient means of creating energy than windmills. These other ways, such as nuclear, are more effective, as they generate more energy at a consistent rate. This proves why wind energy is unreliable and unnecessary.

data_answer: Although wind turbines are a clean source of energy, they also present many issues that counter their productiveness. Another issue concerning their size is the danger they present to the migration paths of certain animals. The large amount of space the blades take up and the speeds at which they turn can kill any bird or animal that comes in contact with the blades. Apart from the issues witht the generators, the turbines can also be very inffevtive. They do not run 24/7 which cuts the amount of energy they can produce. However, if they do run 24/7 they can over heat and destroy the turbine. Their production also depends on the wind; if there is no wind there is no energy being produced. Overall, wind turbines cause more issues than good they contribute to clean energy production. The ineffectiveness and uselessness of wind turbines outweighs their movement for the use of clean energy. The large wind turbine farms do produce energy but they do not produce the maximum they can. Their limited operation hours and vast amount of space taken up can be used better with other sources of energy. With the amount of space they take up, other power plants can be contructed that will result in similar amount of energy, if not more, and cause less problems. Using other forms of energy, clean or not, will cause less direct harm to wildlife and will probably cause less issues concerning the turbine. Alternate forms will also not depend on atmospheric conditions to be able to produce energy. In conclusion, it will be better to invest the money spent on wind turbines on other forms to get the most out of the initial investment of money and space.
